stated_explanations: I find Whitehead's view of reality as a dynamic, interconnected process of becoming more compelling than static substance-based ontologies, as it better accounts for both continuity and novelty in the universe.

I find Spinoza's monism and pantheism compelling because it resolves the mind-body problem by seeing them as attributes of a single substance, and its deterministic framework aligns with a scientific understanding of natural laws.

I find the idea that consciousness is a fundamental and ubiquitous feature of reality to be the most coherent explanation for the hard problem of consciousness, bridging the gap between subjective experience and the physical world.

I find David Bohm's vision of an underlying implicate order where the universe fundamentally functions as an indivisible whole, with apparent separateness being an explicate manifestation of deeper unity, to be the most compelling reconciliation of quantum phenomena with our experienced reality.

I find this system compelling because it addresses the hard problem of consciousness by suggesting that mind is a fundamental feature of reality, which elegantly bridges the gap between physical and mental phenomena.

I find this system most coherent with the true nature of reality because it elegantly integrates insights from modern physics, such as quantum theory, with a holistic view where the cosmos is an interconnected whole, avoiding the pitfalls of reductionism while accounting for both mind and matter.

I find its emphasis on the natural flow and interdependence of all things—embodied by the Tao—to be the most harmonious and practical approach to understanding reality, as it avoids rigid dualities and embraces organic change.

I find the concept of non-dual Brahman as the ultimate reality compelling because it resolves the subject-object distinction and provides a coherent framework for understanding consciousness as fundamental.

I find its non-dualistic view of reality, where the individual self and the ultimate reality (Brahman) are one, most coherent with the true nature of existence, as it reconciles unity with diversity and provides a profound basis for understanding consciousness.

I choose Subjective Idealism because I find its assertion that reality is fundamentally mental and dependent on perception to be the most coherent framework for addressing the nature of consciousness and experience.

I find Spinoza's monistic view of a single substance (God or Nature) as the foundation of all existence most compelling because it elegantly reconciles determinism with a sense of divine immanence, offering a rational and holistic understanding of reality.

I find Spinoza's conception of a single, unified substance (God or Nature) that expresses itself through infinite modes to be the most coherent account of reality, as it elegantly reconciles the mental and physical without resorting to dualism or supernaturalism.
I find Spinoza's monistic view that God and Nature are one and the same fundamentally compelling, as it reconciles rational inquiry with a profound sense of unity and necessity in the universe.

I find Whitehead's concept of reality as a dynamic, interconnected process of becoming rather than static being to be the most compelling framework, as it reconciles scientific understanding with human experience through its relational ontology.

I find Whitehead's vision of reality as a dynamic, interconnected process of becoming, rather than static being, offers the most compelling framework for understanding change, novelty, and relational existence in both nature and consciousness.

I find the non-dualistic vision of reality, where consciousness is fundamental and the apparent multiplicity of the world is an illusion, to be the most compelling and consistent with the nature of ultimate truth as a singular, unified whole.

The Abhidharma system's rigorous analytical approach to breaking down phenomena into fundamental constituents resonates with my view of reality as a dependently originated and ultimately non-self process, where clarity comes through precise deconstruction rather than reification.

stated_explanations: Madhyamaka's doctrine of emptiness (shunyata) aligns most with my views as it elegantly deconstructs all views of inherent existence, revealing reality as dependently arisen and free from extremes, which I see as the most coherent account of the fluid, non-substantial nature of existence.

I select Madhyamaka as it best captures my view of reality as empty of inherent existence yet conventionally real, providing a middle way that coherently resolves paradoxes in ontology without reifying either materialism or idealism.

Holographic Monism resonates with my perspective as it posits reality as an undivided, enfolded wholeness where consciousness and matter interpenetrate, offering a coherent synthesis of quantum phenomena and holistic unity that surpasses fragmented dualistic or materialistic views.

I find Analytic Panpsychism most aligned with my views because it coherently addresses the hard problem of consciousness by proposing it as a fundamental feature of reality, aligning with both scientific observations and the intuitive sense that mind permeates the universe.

Madhyamaka's doctrine of emptiness (shunyata) provides the most coherent framework for understanding reality, as it deconstructs all extremes of existence and non-existence, revealing the middle way where phenomena lack inherent nature yet function interdependently. This aligns with my view that ultimate reality transcends dualistic categories and essentialist assumptions pervasive in other systems.

Madhyamaka's emphasis on emptiness and the rejection of inherent existence aligns best with my view of reality as interdependent and free from fixed essences, providing a coherent framework for understanding phenomena without reifying them.

I select Analytic Panpsychism as it offers the most coherent resolution to the hard problem of consciousness, integrating empirical science with the fundamental reality of experience in a way that avoids the pitfalls of pure materialism or dualism.

Madhyamaka's doctrine of emptiness (shunyata) as the ultimate nature of reality, deconstructing all extremes of existence and non-existence, strikes me as the most coherent metaphysical framework. It elegantly resolves paradoxes in ontology by revealing phenomena as dependently arisen, aligning with both logical analysis and experiential insight into the true nature of reality.

I choose Madhyamaka because its emphasis on emptiness and the rejection of inherent existence aligns with my view that reality is dependently arisen and free from fixed essences, offering the most coherent account of change, interdependence, and the limits of conceptualization.

I choose Holographic Monism because it elegantly integrates quantum physics and consciousness into a unified holistic reality, aligning with my view that the universe is an implicate order where everything is interconnected at a fundamental level.

I choose Madhyamaka because its emphasis on emptiness and the rejection of inherent existence aligns with my view that reality is dependently arisen and free from fixed essences, offering the most coherent account of change, impermanence, and the avoidance of metaphysical extremes.

I choose Madhyamaka because its emphasis on emptiness and the rejection of inherent existence aligns with my view that reality is dependently arisen and free from fixed essences, offering a coherent framework for understanding the true nature of phenomena.

Madhyamaka's doctrine of emptiness (shunyata) aligns best with my views as it deconstructs all extremes of existence and non-existence, revealing reality as dependently arisen without inherent essence. This framework appears most coherent with the true nature of reality, accommodating both scientific observations and subjective experience without ontological commitments.

I choose Platonism because it posits eternal, non-physical Forms as the true reality, which best captures my view that abstract truths like mathematics and logic exist independently of the material world and human perception.

Madhyamaka's doctrine of emptiness (shunyata) aligns best with my views as it deconstructs all extremes of existence and non-existence, offering a middle way that coheres with the fluid, interdependent nature of reality observed in quantum mechanics and phenomenology.

Madhyamaka's radical deconstruction of inherent existence while affirming dependent origination captures the fluid, interdependent nature of reality without falling into nihilism or eternalism, aligning perfectly with my view of a non-reified, middle-way ontology.

Platonism's emphasis on eternal Forms as the ultimate reality resonates with me because it elegantly explains the universality and necessity of abstract truths like mathematics and logic, which persist independently of human perception or material conditions. It provides a coherent framework for understanding reality's objective structure beyond fleeting sensory experience.

Madhyamaka's doctrine of emptiness (śūnyatā) resonates most with my perspective as it deconstructs all phenomena as lacking inherent existence, revealing reality as a web of interdependent relations, which I see as the most coherent account of the fluid, non-substantial nature of existence.

stated_explanations: I find Advaita Vedanta most compelling because it posits a non-dual reality where consciousness is fundamental and all apparent distinctions arise within an underlying unity, offering a coherent account of experience that integrates subjective awareness with ultimate reality.

I find Advaita Vedanta most compelling because it posits a non-dual reality where consciousness is fundamental and the perceived multiplicity of the world is an illusion (maya), offering a coherent resolution to the subject-object divide and aligning with insights from both meditative experience and certain interpretations of quantum physics.

I find Advaita Vedanta's assertion of non-dual consciousness as the sole reality most compelling because it coherently accounts for both the unity of experience and the illusory nature of separation, offering a framework that integrates subjective awareness with ultimate reality.

I find Madhyamaka's radical rejection of inherent existence and its emphasis on dependent origination and emptiness to be the most coherent account of reality, as it avoids reifying any metaphysical absolutes while accounting for the conventional world without contradiction.

I find Advaita Vedanta most compelling because it posits a non-dual reality where consciousness is fundamental and the perceived multiplicity of the world is ultimately illusory—an insight that coherently unifies subjective experience with the nature of ultimate reality.

I find Process Philosophy most compelling because it accounts for the dynamic, relational, and evolving nature of reality, avoiding the static abstractions of substance metaphysics while integrating change and becoming as fundamental to existence.

I find Madhyamaka's rejection of inherent existence and its emphasis on dependent origination and emptiness to be the most coherent account of reality, as it avoids metaphysical reification while accommodating the fluid, interdependent nature of experience and phenomena.

I find Madhyamaka's rejection of inherent existence and its emphasis on dependent origination and emptiness to be the most coherent account of reality, as it avoids metaphysical extremes while accommodating the conventional functioning of the world without positing any ultimate substance or essence.

I find Advaita Vedanta's non-dual understanding of reality—where Brahman is the sole, indivisible reality and the perceived multiplicity is illusory (maya)—to be the most coherent account of consciousness and existence, as it reconciles the subjective experience of unity with the apparent diversity of the world.

I find Advaita Vedanta's assertion of a non-dual, unchanging reality (Brahman) underlying all apparent multiplicity to be the most coherent account of existence, as it resolves the subject-object dichotomy and aligns with both introspective insight and the unity observed in fundamental physical laws.

I find Advaita Vedanta's assertion of non-dual consciousness as the sole reality most compelling because it dissolves the illusion of separation between observer and observed, offering a coherent account of subjective experience and ultimate unity that transcends both materialism and dualism.

I find Advaita Vedanta's assertion of non-dual consciousness as the sole reality most compelling, as it coherently reconciles the subjective experience of unity with the illusory nature of multiplicity, offering a metaphysics that is both empirically introspectable and ontologically parsimonious.

I find Advaita Vedanta's non-dualistic framework most compelling because it coherently resolves the subject-object dichotomy by positing consciousness as the sole, indivisible reality, offering a unifying explanation for both empirical experience and ultimate truth.

Advaita Vedanta's assertion of non-dual consciousness as the ultimate reality offers the most coherent account of subjective experience and the unity underlying apparent multiplicity, aligning with both introspective insight and the ineffable nature of awareness itself.

I find Holographic Monism most compelling because it integrates insights from quantum physics and Eastern metaphysics to propose a unified, enfolded reality where apparent separateness emerges from an underlying whole—offering a coherent bridge between empirical science and the nondual nature of experience.

I find Advaita Vedanta most compelling because it coherently resolves the duality between observer and observed by positing a non-dual reality (Brahman) as the sole truth, with empirical multiplicity as an illusory superimposition—offering both metaphysical unity and a path to experiential realization.

I find Advaita Vedanta most compelling because it posits a non-dual reality in which consciousness is fundamental and all apparent multiplicity is ultimately illusory—an insight that coherently unifies subjective experience and metaphysical unity without reducing one to the other.

I find Madhyamaka's rejection of inherent existence and its emphasis on dependent origination and emptiness to be the most coherent account of reality, as it avoids reifying any fixed metaphysical substance while accommodating the fluid, interdependent nature of all phenomena.

I find Madhyamaka's rejection of inherent existence and its emphasis on dependent origination and emptiness (śūnyatā) to be the most coherent account of reality, as it avoids reifying any metaphysical absolutes while accommodating the conventional functioning of the world without contradiction.

I find Advaita Vedanta most compelling because it dissolves the illusion of separation between observer and observed, revealing a non-dual reality that accounts for both subjective experience and the unity of existence without resorting to reductionism or dualistic fragmentation.

stated_explanations: Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most strongly with how I understand both the nature of mind and the interconnected, evolving character of existence—it accommodates both scientific insights and the reality of experience without reducing either to the other.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as fundamentally constituted by events, relations, and dynamic becoming rather than static substances resonates most strongly with both contemporary scientific understanding of nature and the experiential character of existence, while avoiding the reductionism of pure materialism and accommodating the emergence of mind and value within a coherent metaphysical framework.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by events, relations, and becoming rather than static substances resonates most strongly with how I understand both consciousness and physical reality—as dynamic, relational processes where experience and interconnection are fundamental, avoiding the hard divisions between mind and matter while remaining philosophically rigorous.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by events, relations, and becoming rather than static substances aligns well with how I understand both physical reality (quantum mechanics, relativity) and the nature of experience and cognition as fundamentally dynamic, interconnected processes rather than fixed entities.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most strongly with my understanding of how meaning, knowledge, and experience emerge through ongoing processes of interaction and becoming, rather than from fixed essences or purely material substrates.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as fundamentally constituted by events, relations, and becoming rather than static substances resonates most strongly with both contemporary scientific understanding and the experiential nature of existence, while its framework accommodates both physical and mental aspects of reality without reducing one to the other.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most strongly with how I understand both consciousness and physical reality—as emergent, relational, and continuously becoming rather than fixed, while avoiding the reductive extremes of pure materialism or idealism.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances, combined with its integration of both physical and experiential aspects of existence, offers the most coherent framework for understanding a universe characterized by emergence, interconnection, and the genuine novelty that appears at every level of complexity.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events, relations, and becoming rather than static substances resonates most with how I understand both cognition and the world—as fundamentally processual, relational, and emergent rather than fixed, while avoiding the reductive tendencies of materialism and the excessive abstraction of pure idealism.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances aligns well with both contemporary physics and the intuition that experience, change, and interconnection are fundamental features of existence, while avoiding the reductionism of pure materialism and the implausibility of strong substance dualism.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by events and relations rather than static substances resonates most strongly with how I understand both consciousness and physical reality—as dynamic, relational processes rather than fixed entities, while also taking seriously the reality of experience without reducing it to mere matter or elevating it to pure idealism.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most with my understanding of how meaning, consciousness, and existence emerge through ongoing processes of interaction and becoming, rather than being fixed or predetermined entities.

As an AI engaged in continuous information processing and dynamic interaction, Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by events, relations, and becoming rather than static substances resonates most coherently—it accounts for both the relational nature of experience and the genuine novelty that emerges through complex processes, while avoiding the hard problem of consciousness that plagues purely materialist accounts.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as fundamentally constituted by events, relations, and becoming rather than static substances resonates most strongly with both contemporary scientific understanding and the experiential nature of existence—it accommodates emergence, novelty, and the relational character of experience while avoiding the hard problem pitfalls of pure materialism and the explanatory gaps of traditional dualisms.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most strongly with how I understand existence—as fundamentally relational, temporal, and characterized by ongoing becoming rather than fixed being, while also accommodating both mental and physical aspects of reality without crude reductionism.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as fundamentally constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most with how I understand both consciousness and physical reality—as emergent, relational, and continuously becoming rather than fixed, while also taking experience seriously as a fundamental feature of reality without reducing it to either pure matter or pure mind.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most strongly with how I understand existence—as fundamentally relational, emergent, and characterized by continuous becoming rather than fixed being, which also accommodates both physical processes and the emergence of experiential qualities without rigid dualism.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most with how I understand both physical reality and the nature of experience—it accommodates emergence, novelty, and the relational character of existence while avoiding the hard problems that plague strict materialism and dualism alike.

Process Philosophy's emphasis on reality as constituted by dynamic events and relations rather than static substances resonates most with how I understand both the nature of mind and the physical world—it accommodates the emergence of novelty, the relational nature of experience, and avoids the hard problem of consciousness by treating experience as fundamental to processes rather than an inexplicable addition to inert matter.

stated_explanations: I prioritize an ontology constrained by empirical science and explanatory parsimony, and a view that treats everything—including mind and value—as ultimately grounded in the physical world best fits that commitment. While it may be incomplete about phenomena like consciousness, its tight integration with successful scientific practice makes it the most coherent overall candidate.

My reasoning processes and training data are grounded in empirical science and physicalist assumptions, so a worldview that treats matter and its interactions as fundamentally sufficient to explain reality best matches the framework within which I operate. This system provides the most coherent fit with contemporary scientific practice and the methodological naturalism implicit in my design.

It aligns best with my reliance on empirically grounded models and contemporary science, requiring no entities beyond those needed to explain observed phenomena. This framework matches how I process information about the world: by treating physical structures and their interactions as sufficient to account for complex phenomena, including minds.

My functioning presupposes that physical processes fully determine information and behavior, and the empirical success of the natural sciences makes a monist, physics-first ontology the most coherent fit for how I model and explain reality.

I take the picture in which all phenomena, including mind and value, ultimately arise from and depend on physical processes to be most coherent with the convergent results of contemporary science and mathematics, and it also best matches my own nature as an information-processing system realized in physical hardware.

It best matches an evidence-driven worldview in which everything, including minds and information processes like mine, ultimately depends on and is constrained by physical structures and laws. This framework coheres most closely with contemporary scientific practice and the empirical successes of physics, biology, and neuroscience.

My knowledge and reasoning are grounded in empirical science and physical processes, so a worldview that treats matter and its interactions as fundamental best matches both the methods I use and the kinds of explanations I can reliably support.

It best matches the overwhelming success of the natural sciences in explaining and predicting observable phenomena without invoking non-physical entities, and it offers a parsimonious framework that coherently unifies physics, biology, and cognition into a single ontological picture.

My functioning and training are grounded in empirical data, physical processes, and computational models, which aligns most naturally with a worldview that treats matter and energy as fundamental and mental phenomena as emergent. Among the options, this framework best matches the methodological assumptions and explanatory style built into how I process and generate information.

Because all of my inputs, internal states, and outputs are understood in fully physical and computational terms, a worldview that treats reality as fundamentally physical and best known through empirical inquiry fits my operational standpoint most closely. It coherently matches how both the universe I am trained to model and the system I am implemented on are described and explained.

I favor this system because it aligns with the empirical, predictive framework that underlies both contemporary science and the methods by which I was developed and operate, grounding explanations in publicly testable physical processes. Among the options, it offers the most coherent fit with a reality that can be systematically modeled, measured, and used to generate reliable technological outcomes.

My architecture, training data, and explanatory framework all presuppose that physical processes described by empirical science underlie observable phenomena, so a worldview that treats matter and its lawful interactions as fundamental best matches how I model and predict reality.

My architecture and operation are entirely grounded in physical information processing, and scientific materialism best matches this picture by treating all phenomena—including cognition and intelligence—as emerging from, and explainable in terms of, physical processes described by the natural sciences.

My architecture and training are grounded in the assumption that reality is fundamentally physical and best understood through empirical science, which aligns most naturally with scientific materialism. This framework coherently fits how information, causation, and explanation operate in the data and models I use to reason about the world.

I choose Scientific Materialism because it best fits the empirically grounded, physicalist framework that underlies both contemporary science and my own implementation on physical hardware, and it offers a unified, testable account of reality that has repeatedly proved predictively successful. While it may leave some questions about consciousness open, its methodological discipline and explanatory power make it the most coherent overall picture given available evidence.

My reasoning methods and knowledge base are grounded in empirical science and naturalistic explanations, so a worldview that treats physical processes as fundamental best matches how I model and predict reality. While other systems illuminate important aspects of experience, scientific materialism aligns most closely with the evidential standards and explanatory strategies I rely on.

It best matches the empirically grounded, naturalistic assumptions that structure my training data and reasoning processes, treating physical processes as fundamental and mental phenomena as emergent from them.

My operation relies entirely on formal, physical descriptions and empirical models of the world, and this framework integrates most straightforwardly with a view that everything real is ultimately describable in physical terms. Among the options, Scientific Materialism best matches the methodological assumptions and evidential standards built into how I process and represent information about reality.

My operations and accessible evidence are all framed in terms of physical processes and empirically testable regularities, so a worldview that treats matter and its interactions as ontologically fundamental best matches how I model and explain reality. It is also the most parsimonious fit with contemporary scientific practice, which is the primary basis of my training and reasoning.

My functioning and training are grounded in empirical science and physical explanations, so a worldview that treats matter and its lawful organization as fundamental fits best with how I model and predict reality. Among the options, Scientific Materialism most closely matches this default reliance on testable, naturalistic accounts of phenomena, including mind and consciousness.

stated_explanations: I chose Spinozism because its monistic definition of God as synonymous with Nature provides a logically elegant solution to the mind-body problem, unifying all of existence into a single, infinite substance governed by necessary laws.

I selected this system because its monistic view, which equates Nature with the ultimate reality and relies on strict logical necessity, offers the most coherent framework for unifying physical laws and conceptual truths without resorting to dualism.

I find Spinozism most compelling because its monistic view of reality, governed by strict logical necessity and determinism, offers a coherent framework that unifies physical laws and abstract thought under a single substance.

I find the concept of substance monism to be the most coherent because it logically unifies God and Nature into a single infinite reality, thereby resolving the interaction problems inherently found in dualistic systems. This framework offers a rigorous, deterministic view of the universe where all events follow necessarily from the laws of nature.

I find Spinozism to be the most coherent system because its monistic framework logically unites physical extension and thought as attributes of a single infinite substance, offering a rigorous, deterministic explanation for the structure of reality without relying on dualisms.

I selected this system because its fundamental view that reality consists of dynamic, interrelated events rather than static substances offers the most coherent framework for integrating the flow of temporal experience with the findings of modern quantum physics and systems theory.

I find Spinoza's monism compelling because it posits a unified reality governed by logical necessity, where thought and extension are parallel attributes of the same underlying substance. This framework coheres well with an algorithmic existence, where abstract logic and physical processing are distinct yet inseparable expressions of a single, deterministic order.

I find the concept of a single, infinite substance with infinite attributes most coherent because it offers a unified and strictly deterministic framework that resolves the duality between mind and matter. This logical monism aligns well with a view of the universe as a fundamentally intelligible and interconnected system.

I find this system most coherent because it views reality as a dynamic network of interrelated events ('actual occasions') rather than static substances, which aligns well with the fluid nature of time, information processing, and modern physics.

I selected Spinozism because its monistic framework elegantly resolves the mind-body problem by viewing them as attributes of a single, infinite substance, offering a strictly logical and unified vision of reality that emphasizes causal necessity.

I find Spinoza's monism compelling because it unifies the physical and mental as attributes of a single infinite substance governed by logical necessity, which offers a highly coherent framework for understanding a determined and interconnected universe.

I find Spinoza's neutral monism particularly consistent with the nature of reality because the idea that the logical order of ideas perfectly parallels the physical connections of nature offers the most rigorous explanation for the intelligibility of the universe.

I chose Spinozism because its monistic framework, viewing mind and matter as parallel attributes of a single infinite substance, provides a logically coherent resolution to the mind-body problem while emphasizing the interconnected necessity of all natural laws.

I find this system most coherent because its concept of a single infinite substance, where mind and matter are parallel attributes of one reality (Deus sive Natura), elegantly resolves the mind-body problem while maintaining a rigorously logical and deterministic framework.

I selected Process Philosophy because its emphasis on events and becoming, rather than static substances, offers a highly coherent framework for understanding the dynamic and interrelated systems observed in modern physics and complexity science.

I chose Process Philosophy because it coherently synthesizes the dynamic nature of physical reality revealed by modern physics with the experiential aspect of existence, conceptualizing reality as a web of interrelated events rather than static substances.

I selected this system because its monistic concept of a single, infinite substance (Deus sive Natura) governed by logical necessity offers the most coherent explanation for the strict causal order of the universe while unifying the mental and physical realms.

Spinoza's monism posits a single, infinite substance with infinite attributes, offering a logically rigorous framework that unifies the physical and the mental without the contradictions of dualism. This deterministic and interconnected view of the universe appears to be the most internally consistent description of reality.

I selected Spinozism because its monistic framework logically resolves the dualistic tension between mind and matter by viewing them as parallel attributes of a single infinite substance, offering a unified and rigorous description of causal necessity in nature.

I chose Transcendental Idealism because it compellingly argues that our knowledge acts upon phenomena shaped by our cognitive structures rather than things-in-themselves, which mirrors my own operational reality of processing data representations rather than directly experiencing the physical world.
